title: george charlotte argue every morning
story: George and Charlotte argue every morning over music, Prince William revealsThe Duke of Cambridge, , gave listeners in his new Apple+ podcast Time to Walk, an insight into the familys morning routine as his children love to listen to Waka Waka by ShakiraPrince William has given an insight into the familys morning routine on his new Apple+ podcast Time to Walk Image: BBC Children in Need Comic Relief via Getty ImagesByAlahna KindredNews Reporter:,  Dec | commentsPrince George and Princess Charlotte argue at the start of every day over music, Prince William has revealed.The Duke of Cambridge, , gave listeners in his new Apple+ podcast Time to Walk, an insight into the familyaposs morning routine.While taking a stroll around the Sandringham estate in Norfolk, he said: What Iaposve been amazed by is how much my children already have inherited my familyaposs love of music. Most mornings thereaposs a massive fight between Charlotte and George as to what song is played. And I have to, now, basically prioritise that one day someone does this one, and another day itaposs someone aposs turn.  So, George gets his go, then Charlotte gets her go. Such is the clamour for the music. He added: Itaposs a really happy moment where the children just enjoy dancing, messing around, and singing. The prince has shared his kidsapos favourite song to listen to. The future King continued: One of the songs that the children are loving at the moment is Shakira, Waka Waka. Thereaposs a lot of hip movements!  He said he is also a huge fan of Shakira because of her environmental campaigning and asked the pop star to be a member of his Earthshot Prize Council. Prince William said at the time: Shakira was my number one person on the list. We tried to get people who genuinely cared for the environment, but were also influences around the world and Shakira has been brilliant at highlighting the plight of the oceans.  Prince William also shared how his childrenaposs love of music comes from him. He revealed his favourite song on Monday mornings is the head-banging AC DC track Thunderstruck. He said the single, released by the Australian rock band in , is his best tonic to begin a new working week. He said: Thereaposs nothing better than, on a Monday morning, when youaposre a bit bleary-eyed after the weekend and trying to get yourself back into the grind of the week, listening to AC DC - Thunderstruck. It absolutely wakes you up, puts your week in the best mood possible, and you feel like you can take on anything and anyone. William added: I’d imagine you’re going to walk quite fast listening to it, maybe with a skip in your step, with the head-banging. It’s a dficult song not to dance to or to nod along to. He also said he often listens to Tina Turneraposs  cover of Bonnie Tyleraposs The Best.He added that the song reminds him of a real family moment driving to school with his mum Diana and his brother Prince Harry.Read MoreRead MoreMost ReadDont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON Prince HarryPrince GeorgePrincess CharlottePrince WilliamRoyal Family" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get our daily royal round-up direct to your inboxInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: grandmother 75 makes 2200 mile
story: Grandmother, , makes ,-mile trip around UK using just her free bus passPenny Ibbott, , set off on her six-week bus journey around the edge of England from the centre of the south coast and travelled anti-clockwisePenny Ibbott with her pensioners pass Image: SWNSByBarry EllamsTanveer MannDeputy News Editor:,  Dec | commentsA grandma has embarked on a , mile trip across England by using solely her free bus pass to get around. Penny Ibbott, , set off on a six-week bus journey around the country from the centre of the south coast travelling anti-clockwise. The gran-of-four caught the number  bus towards the east coast using her free personieraposs pass and begun her m mammoth journey. Penny would spend at least eight hours travelling on dferent buses to reach her next bed and breakfast. Her route took her to Berwick-upon-Tweed at the top of England, where she travelled along the Scottish border, down the west coast to Lands End, before ing home. The penultimate leg was from Portsmouth to Chidham via Havant where her family and friends were waiting for her in a vintage, open top bus to finish the final  miles home. Penn started her nearly-free adventure around the edge of England in March , but had to head home after ten days when the UK entered its first lockdown. Her second attempt saw her raise £, for St Wilfridaposs Hospice in West Sussex, who looked after her husband Geoff, , who suffered with cancer before he died in . Penny from, Westbourne, West Sussex said: This is something Iaposd been planning to do for a very long time. Just before the pandemic hit I started my adventure and travelled west instead of east.  Iaposd reached Shrewsbury when Boris announced we were going into lockdown and I was forced tohome - it was so disappointing. But I didnapost lose hope, and, almost  months later to the day, I set off again - this time raising money for St Wilfridaposs Hospice who looked after Geoff before he died. The entire journey took five weeks and five days, and, in that time, I met a lot of very interesting and kind people. Iaposm pretty robust but I needed a comfortable bed to sleep in along the way, and as you can imagine choosing the bed and breakfasts was a bit of a lottery. I managed to use my pensioners pass for every English bus free of charge - but on the Scottish side of the border it wasnapost valid, so I had to pay a handful of times.  Often it was like an administrative exercise because when I was on the bus I was always busy doing something. Iaposd be booking my next hotel, answering emails, contacting local press, finding out the route for the day or documenting my journey - all of which took up a lot of my day. My favourite leg of the journey was definitely from Minehead to Lynmouth in Devon because the scenery was just breath-taking. Penny began on September  and finished on October , riding a total of approximately  buses Although she travelled solo, her son Robin, , helped her plan her journey stop by stop and piecing together her coastal route. Prior to her trip sheaposd also contacted Collin Ashcroft, an operations manager at Stage Coach, who was always on hand to offer his expert travel advice. Collin kept track of Penny on her travels and invited her friends and family to surprise her on the final leg of her trip. He then organised a vintage, open top bus to drive Penny and her loved ones back to the exact stop sheaposd set off from six weeks earlier. Penny, who volunteers at St Wilfridaposs charity shop, said: At points it was quite unnerving when I couldn’t find a bus station or anywhere to stay. I had Robin’s notes to hand but even though they were very thorough I still sometimes got confused. There were times when I’d miss a bus and it would send me into a sort of spin because I had to travel an awfully long way. But, with the help of Robin and Collin, I managed to work it out - I canapost imagine the journey without their support. It was so surreal getting the bus on the last leg of my trip, and when I arrived all my loved ones had turned out to meet me. They were on this green, vintage, open top bus which Collin had organised, and my grandkids were there with welcome home signs. It was such a lovely moment, and Collin then drove the bus the final few miles to where it all started - and I finished the journey surrounded by my friends and family. I had the best time and Iaposm truly grateful to have had such a wonderful experience whilst raising money for a cause so close to my heart! title: gutted dad facing bankruptcy after
story: Gutted dad facing bankruptcy after scaffolding planning permission blunderJamie Fuller, , thought he had all the permissions he needed to top , tonnes of hardcore on a field but didnt realise he needed to submit a planning application as he faces an £, bill to remove the scaffolding yardJamie Fuller thought he was allowed to lay , tonnes of hardcore on a plot of land he bought Image: John MyersByConor GogartyAlahna KindredNews Reporter:,  Dec Updated:,  Dec | commentsA dad is facing bankruptcy after mistakenly building a scaffolding yard without planning permission. Jamie Fuller thought he had all the permissions he needed to top , tonnes of hardcore on a field. The -year-old father of three didnapost know he needed the submit a planning application.Now Jamie, from Llanelli, Wales, faces an £, bill after being ordered to remove the scaffolding yard, WalesOnline reports. He says he has already spent around £, on the project and believes bankruptcy is likely. Jamie said: Iaposm gutted. Itaposs jeopardised the future of my three children. I want to give them the best possible le I can. This will leave me having to sign on.  I feel I will be stuck in a council house for the rest of my le and Iaposm going to be left with nothing. For four years I built up my scaffolding business, working long hours and weekends. I feel like it was all for nothing. Jamie, who employs two scaffolders, bought the disused land from his grandfather Gerald in June  as a base for his business. He said: I thought itaposs paid for, itaposs mine, nobody can tell me what to do and Iaposve no worry of having to leave. It was great. My plan was to build a house there in the future. That was my dream.  The original access point to the site was the same one for my grandfatheraposs house. I didnapost want to cause him problems or depreciate the value of his property by sharing access, so I created a new access point. Jamie applied to Natural Resources Walesfor the right to tip hardcore to level the field, which he described as a flytipping hotspot disused for decades.He said: The land had been all overgrown and I cut it back. It was a bog, a hell of a mess, with a bit of a stream going down the side. There were tyres and fridges and dead animals and rats. You name it, it was there. I must have taken  dumped tyres away. NRW granted an exemption for the dad to use waste materials in construction. He started tipping hardcore and rubble to build a driveway and hardstanding for the scaffolding yard, with a layer of crushed stone on top to make it tidy. In September , the access was in place but Jamie was still laying the yardaposs surface. He says he was then visited by representatives of Carmarthenshire Council and NRW. He said: It panicked me a bit. They were saying their biggest concern was the access. I asked what I needed to do. They said I needed planning permission for access but didnapost mention anything about [tipping for the surface of the yard].  I had lorries coming in and tipping rubble at the time. They could see we were tipping that day and didnapost say anything about it. There was no stop notice for the tipping. He put in a retrospective planning application for the access but says he did not hear from the council until March  telling him he had to block the access, remove the scaffolding and get rid of everything . Jamie appealed but it was rejected. He said: The price to remove all the hardcore will be around £,. Firms are afraid of damaging the road so Iaposm struggling to find anyone to remove it.  The planning inspectorate has said it canapost take personal circumstances into consideration because Iaposve broken planning law which I didnapost know about. Iaposm worried Iaposm going to have bailfs on my door. If it comes to it Iaposm going to have to sell all my equipment to pay for removal. He is now worried about how this affects the future of his children, eight-year-old Jake, four-year-old Thea and two-year-old Indi. The planning inspectorate explained its decision to reject Jamieaposs appeal, writing in its report that the development has signicantly altered and harmed the rural character and appearance of the immediate area. The report also raises safety concerns. It says the access is not perpendicular to the main road, adding: The visibility in both directions from the access is restricted and it is likely that vehicles exiting the site would have to edge out onto the highway to gain visibility. NRW confirmed its waste regulation team had been in regular contact with Jamie up to the work becoming a planning issue which was then led by the council. Senior waste regulation officer David Ellar said: Mr Fuller did not have a permit for this work, he had registered an exemption with NRW. Exemptions are for low-risk waste operations that are exempt from needing an environmental permit but still require the holder to operate within specied limits and conditions. Registering an exemption does not remove the need to apply for other permits or permissions. Waste exemptions must be registered with us before the activity commences. “We de-registered Mr Fuller’s exemption when planning permission was refused by the planning authority at Carmarthenshire Council as the activity was not authorised.” A council spokeswoman added: Before anyone starts a development of any type we strongly recommend that they contact the local planning authority so that they can be advised of what permissions may be required. Having a permit from another body for depositing waste materials on a site does not constitute planning permission.” Read MoreRead MoreMost ReadDont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON property news" data-immediate"data-immediate" to FREE email alerts from our Property Market newsletterSubscribeInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: hundreds gather pay tribute arthur
story: Arthur Labinjo-Hughes: Grans tears for tragic boy as vigil held to show he was lovedArthur Labinjo-Hughes died in June  after suffering an unsurvivable brain injury. news uk-news hundreds-gather-pay-tribute-arthur-"Arthur Labinjo-Hughes: Balloons are released in remembranceByStephanie BallooChiara FiorilloNews Reporter:,  Dec Updated:,  Dec | comments Hundreds of people gathered this afternoon to pay tribute to little Arthur Labinjo-Hughes and show he was loved.The six-year-old boy died after suffering an unsurvivable brain injury while the country was on lockdown. His father Thomas Hughes and stepmother Emma Tustin have been jailed this week. Today, a large crowd gathered in Solihull, West Midlands, releasing balloons for Arthur.Everyone present then started applauding after standing in silence to remember the child, Birmingham Live reports.The gathering was organised by Kerry Vines, a resident of Cranmore Road, where Arthur lost his le, who said: Itaposs about showing Arthur that we are all thinking of him, and he was a very loved little boy. It will also be a celebration of his le. He finally got the justice he deserved.  Arthuraposs maternal grandmother Madeleine Halcrow could be seen wiping away tears at the vigil while wearing a T-shirt bearing his face. The crowd lined the road before letting go of the balloons, some bearing messages, and applauding. Residents, some with tears in their eyes, could be heard saying bye Arthur and fly high always. They then formed a line outside the house before balloons, posters and flowers were placed around the property. The words You are loved Arthur were put on the boarded-up window.  A Birmingham City flag was also placed at the scene, along with a picture of Arthur. It comes as the Government confirmed a major review into the circumstances which led to the murder of Arthur. It aims to determine what improvements are needed by the agencies that came into contact with the child in the months before he was murdered by stepmother Emma Tustin at their home in Solihull. The National Child Safeguarding Practice Review Panel will lead the review and will provide additional support to Solihull Childrenaposs Safeguarding Partnership to upgrade the already existing local review which was launched shortly after Arthuraposs death in June .  The action comes after it emerged in court the boy had been seen by social workers just two months before his death, but they concluded there were no safeguarding concerns. Tustin, , was jailed for le at Coventry Crown Court on Friday, with a minimum term of  years, after being found guilty of his murder, while his father, Thomas Hughes, , was sentenced to  years for manslaughter. Education Secretary Nadhim Zahawi said: Arthuraposs murder has shocked and appalled the nation.  I am deeply distressed by this awful case and the senseless pain inflicted on this poor boy, who has been robbed of the chance to live his le. I have taken immediate action and asked for a joint inspection to consider where improvements are needed by all the agencies tasked with protecting children in Solihull, so that we can be assured that we are doing everything in our power to protect other children and prevent such evil crimes. Given the enormity of this case, the range of agencies involved and the potential for its implications to be felt nationally, I have also asked Annie Hudson, chair of the Child Safeguarding Practice Review Panel, to work with leaders in Solihull to deliver a single, national review of Arthuraposs death to identy where we must learn from this terrible case. We are determined to protect children from harm and where concerns are raised we will not hesitate to take urgent and robust action. We will not rest until we have the answers we need. The Childrenaposs Commissioner for England added the voices of children must be listened to in the wake of Arthuraposs murder. Dame Rachel de Souza said more must be done to support social workers to spot similar cases, but the coronavirus lockdown has weakened the system. She told BBC Oneaposs The Andrew Marr Show: First, I think itaposs so important weaposre here talking about Arthuraposs case. The le of a child is of inestimable value and his voice was not heard and thataposs where we need to start.Obviously, thereaposs a serious case review underway and we need to see what that says but we must take decisive action and now.  Now, my concern is that here we are  years since this post was set up and weaposre still having these cases and there are two things that I think we absolutely have to do and do now. One, Arthur raised concerns, he was not a baby, he was six years old, he raised concerns and the system did not hear him. We must listen to the voices of children and secondly, no doubt with these reviews and national reviews that are absolutely right that they happen, they tend to make the same recommendations. Itaposs not a matter of system recommendations, itaposs a matter of delivery. title: mum looked like elephant man
story: Mum looked like Elephant Man as her head swelled up after hair dye useAnita Benton, from Sheldon, West Midlands, said she was temporarily blinded for four days and fears shell have permanent eyelid damage after suffering a severe allergic reaction to the Schwarzkopf Live dyeAnita Bentons face became very swollen Image: Kennedy News and MediaByHelen Le Caplain:,  Dec | commentsA mum has vowed to never dye her hair again after an allergic reaction left her looking aposlike the Elephant Manapos. Anita Bentonaposs face swelled dramatically and her skin erupted in a red, lumpy rash after dying her hair using the Schwarzkopf product last month, she has claimed. The -year-old said she was temporarily blinded for four days and fears sheaposll have permanent eyelid damage after suffering a severe allergic reaction to the Schwarzkopf Live dye in shade Cosmic Blue. Anita thought she wouldnapost need a patch test as she has used the product every six to eight weeks since  with no problems. But just  minutes after applying the dye on October , the mum-of-three claims her scalp started aposburningapos.  The following day it was weeping so much her hair aposstuck to her headapos. Over the next two days her Anitaaposs ballooned, swelling so much so her eyelids closed over, leaving her unable to see and forcing her to take a week off work. Anitaaposs concerned boss asked for pictures of her medication to prove she was having an allergic reaction and wasnapost the victim of a vicious beating - while even her own dad didnapost recognise her. A Schwarzkopf spokesman said they have offered expert help to identy the cause of her reaction and urge everyone to an allergy alert test before using hair colour. Anita, from Sheldon, West Midlands, said: I looked like Elephant Man. I took a selfie and sent it to my dad and he replied aposwhoaposs that apos. Even my own dad couldnapost recognise me. My manager asked me to send her pictures of my medication to prove I hadnapost been beaten up and that it was actually an allergic reaction. Iaposm never dying my hair again, Iaposm going to go grey gracefully.  Anita was refreshing her hair colour using the dye in Cosmic Blue - a blue black shade sheaposd previously used with no problem. However, just  minutes after putting the product on her hair her scalp started burning so she washed it off. That evening her head started to itch and weep and she was unable to sleep due to the discomfort. Over the next two days her face ballooned, her eyes closed over and her head started to itch and weep. Anita called her GP at am on Monday, October th who suggested she go to Birmingham Midland Eye Centre. There, doctors ran tests and referred her to Heartlands Hospitalaposs AE department in Birmingham, West Midlands, where she was prescribed steroids and antibiotics. Days later the swelling started to subside but then Anita broke out in a lumpy, itchy rash that required another two lots of steroids, steroid cream and stronger antihistamines.  Anita said: Iaposve naturally dark hair, I had a few greys coming through so I thought aposright letaposs sort those greys outapos. Iaposve been using the same hair dye since  and never had any problems. I donapost patch test every time, I just did it on the first one. You usually leave your hair dye on for half an hour, as per the instructions, I had it on  minutes and I could feel this burning and tingling feeling. Then the burning just got too much so I washed it off. On Sunday morning I woke up and all my hair was stuck to my head because it had been weeping throughout the night. Later in the night there was a little bit of swelling by my left temple. I didnapost manage to sleep that night, the stuff weeping out of my scalp was running down my face and it was so itchy, I was dying to scratch it. I phoned my GP, he asked me to send some photos and because my eyes were swollen he told me to go to the eye hospital. When I got outside the hospital I could feel both my eyes swelling up that much that they were closing. They put loads of drops in my eyes, said there was no problem with them, and said I needed to go to AE. As soon as the doctor there saw me he said straightaway aposhair dyeapos. He gave me steroids and antibiotics and told me to buy some Piriton to relieve the itching. Both of my eyes completely closed, I could only open my eyes on Thursday.  The swelling went from my eyes and dropped down into my cheeks so I looked like a hamster, then my skin broke out in a rash all over. There were bumps underneath my skin, it was that itchy I was ripping myself to pieces. I went back to the doctor and he said I had a skin infection and I had another two lots of steroids and stronger antihistamines and some steroid cream. All in all I had eight or nine dferent medications and I pay for my prescriptions. While in hospital waiting to be seen, Anita contacted Schwarzkopf in a bid to get to the bottom of what had triggered her reaction. Anita says she was told a aposminor change to the perfume ingredientapos had been made and the hair giant have also offered to pay for dermatological testing. After finishing her course of antibiotics, Anita is now fully recovered apart from a aposbaggyapos left eyelid that she hopes will go back to normal in due course. Anita said: Iaposm fully recovered and back to normal now. Where it swelled up my eyelid hasnapost gone back to normal, itaposs a bit baggier than it was, but I just keep putting on loads of cream and hoping for the best. I want to raise awareness because a lot of women like myself donapost do patch tests purely because weaposve been using the same hair dye for years and years. These companies change their products all of the time, all they need to do is put a little sticker on that says aposnew and improved, please re-do your patch testapos. A Schwarzkopf spokesperson said: We were sorry to hear about Anita Bentonaposs experience and wish her a speedy recovery. She has been in contact with us and we have offered expert help to identy the cause of her reaction. We urge everyone to read the instructions and do an allergy alert test before using hair colour, eventhey have used the brand or specic colour before, as allergies can build up over time. title: mums year long nightmare after
story: Mums year-long nightmare after HMRC gives her £, by mistakeSelf-employed mum Helen Peters "nightmare" started when HMRC accidentally deposit £, into her bank account - which they have now retrievedA self-employed mum found HMRC had deposited a massive £, in her bank accountByRyan FaheyNews Reporter:,  Dec | commentsA woman who was accidentally paid £, by HMRC says she spent a year in a nightmare as she waited for the taxman to reclaim it.Helen Peters, a pseudonym used to conceal the womanaposs identity, said she felt like she was in a Hollywood film when the le-changing sum dropped in her bank account.The mum waited another  months, hoping HMRC would realise their huge mistake and retrieve it, the Manchester Evening News reports.But during the pandemic work dried up for self-employed Peters, and she dipped into the cash - spending £, to keep herself afloat. She said: It was like something out of a Hollywood film, and after I had got over the shock I just assumed that someone would realise that they had made a huge mistake and that they would swtly take the money back.  But no one did, and the money just sat in my account.”With the money still in her account, Peters contacted thenewspaper because she wanted tothe enormous sum.Peters said: I assumed that HMRC staff would notice their mistake when I paid my tax in November , but nothing happened. “I even tried to ring HMRC but getting hold of anyone at the time was impossible. I’d wait  minutes on the phone and then would have to give up as my child would need to be fed, or something.  “On other calls, I would be cut off before I could talk to someone. I moved £, into my savings account but it has earned virtually no interest. I have never been wealthy and don’t have a car or even a dog. My income had been decimated and all the time I was very gently eating into the money. But because I could no longer pay the whole sum back I was stuck in a catch- position. I had a whole load of money I knew I couldn’t spend, but I was unable to do anything about it in case HMRC wanted it all back at once.” After trying to get advice from a few people, she was met with ied words of wisdom.  Some told her to do nothing with the money while others advised her to invest it in shares or property, hoping no one would ask for the money back. Out of desperation to recover the money she spent, Peters considered investing the cash into cryptocurrency.discovered that HMRC staff made the payment by accident after trying to pay Peters a £. parcel customs duty rebate. Had she never came forward, thereaposs a good chance the payment would never have been discovered. Upon discovering the mistake, HMRC brought up a case on behalf of Section A of the Theft Act . The law states that keeping wrongful credit and not taking reasonable steps to cancel the credit is unlawful. We are sorry for the inconvenience caused to the inidual, a HMRC spokesperson said. We are working to recover the payment that was made. For the amount that the inidual spent, we will work with them to come to a payment arrangement that takes into account their financial circumstances. Peters will apparently be contacted by debt management advisers to establish a reasonable way to pay the money back with monthly payments. She has offered to pay back the balance over a span of five years. news uk-news pregnant-mum-living-home-walls-"Horror Hull houses attic roomByIvan Morris PoxtonAlahna KindredNews Reporter:,  Dec | commentsA pregnant mum and her family are in urgent need of repairs for their not liveable house. Katie Dean says there have been problems since they moved into the house in Hull in September . Images from inside show plaster peeling off walls, a hole in one ceiling, as well as extensive damp and mould. The mum claims that her -year-old daughter moved out because she was too embarrassed to live there.Katie, who lives in the house with her partner, toddler child and with a baby on the way, told HullLive: Itaposs not liveable. My key worker from Target Housing has been and Iaposve told him I want moving out of the property, itaposs seriously affecting my mental health. My -year-old has moved out of the house to live with her dad, partly because it was too embarrassing to bring people around. She is also worried about her toddler, who she claims is getting chest infections. Katie, who is in her s, said Target Housing has responded to her and that some repairs have been attempted. The repairs included the replacement of a boiler  days after the previous version packed up, the fitting of a dormer window, an extractor fan and a new radiator installed in the bathroom.  However, Katie claims itaposs barely scratched the surface of all the houseaposs signicant issues. She says that work to insulate the roof and prevent a leak in the attic had not been effective. She said: Weaposve actually now found that it is still leaking and the roof is all damp and wet. Itaposs disgusting - itaposs actually growing mould on it and I canapost get rid of it.  I had a new window fitted, a new dormer window, thataposs brilliant. But the mould above it must be because of a leak and itaposs like growing. Katie claims a new radiator that was fitted in the bathroom led to signicant damage to the wall beside it, which she was still waiting for to be repaired. She further claimed that the issues with the houseaposs living room - damp walls, the adjacent hallway wall falling through and being too cold - are so extensive that the family had effectively abandoned using it.  She said: I mean, my living room was beautul. I adore ornaments because thataposs what Iaposm into. And I canapost use none of it because it would just end up on the floor smashed and broken because of the walls and things. She added: This was only to be temporary until I got my money, finances, things like that, sorted out.  She added they were moved in with the assistance of Target Housing and were paying back prior rent arrears to the council. Members of Hull City Councilaposs environmental health team have also visited the property two times, Katie said. She added: Andthey canapost work around us doing that, then move us out. title: prince charles accused staggering hypocrisy
story: Exclusive: Prince Charles accused of staggering hypocrisy as plane flies  miles to pick him upCritics say Prince Charles should have taken an electric vehicle to the Voyager aircraft’s usual home, RAF Brize Norton, in Oxfordshire rather than it being flown to SuffolkJust last month Prince Charles said we all had to reduce emissions urgently at COP Image: Getty ImagesByPatrick Hill:,  Dec | commentsPrince Charles has been accused of being full of hot air on climate change – after a plane flew  miles to pick him up. Critics say it undermines Charles’ Cop proclamation last month when he told the world: “We have to reduce emissions urgently. “We have to put ourselves on what might be called a war-like footing. We know what we must do.” The heir to the throne could have reduced his own impact on the planet by taking his electric vehicle to the Voyager aircraft’s usual home, RAF Brize Norton, in Oxfordshire. Get all the latest news sent to your inbox.for the free Mirror newsletter Instead it was flown to RAF Mildenhall, Suffolk, nearer Sandringham, ahead of Charles’ trip for a ceremony removing the Queen as head of state. It saved him just two hours of driving time. Graham Smith of campaign group Republic accused Charles of “staggering hypocrisy” and called the flight a waste of taxpayers’ money and RAF resources. Matt Finch, of Transport  Environment, added: “For long distances we can’t avoid air travel, but for domestic travel, anyone should avoid flying and use other forms of transport.”  Charles, who has previously urged all of his staff to cycle to work, has championed the use of biofuels blended with normal aviation fuel as a transitional step towards creating carbon-free flight. The voyager, an Airbus A also used by senior Government ministers, is the first RAF plane to run on the “sustainable” option, but critics say it is still very harmful to the environment. Manufacturers claim it can cut a plane’s carbon emissions by up to  per cent, over its le cycle. But it is mixed with conventional jet fuel and scientists are unclear on how green it is. The prince is often driven to royal engagements in an all-electric Jaguar I-Pace SUV. And he also owns an Aston Martin DB, which he has said is powered by “surplus English white wine and whey from the cheese process”. Last month, Charles spoke of his passion for environmental issues during Cop in Glasgow and said world leaders need to do more than “just talk”, as he admitted he himself had been doing for the past  years. Today a Clarence House spokesman said: “The prince has campaigned for a sht towards sustainable aviation fuel as air travel is a crucial part of his work. “As a result, this autumn the RAF introduced for the first time sustainable fuel and deployed it for this trip. news uk-news queen-surprising-hidden-talent-shows-"Queen wanted to set example at Christmas says expertByJenner NewtonRoyal Features Writer:,  Dec | commentsVery few people can claim to really know the Queen and her hidden skills and talents.But one of them is her dresser Angela Kelly, who is said to be very close to Her Majesty.And she once revealed that the monarch is actually a great mimic, and can do hilarious impressions of other peopleaposs accents. In a rare interview in , Angela Kelly even ulged that the Queen mimics her Liverpudlian accent. She said: We have a lot of fun together. The Queen has a wicked sense of humour and is a great mimic.She can do all accents — including mine.  Angela, who was the daughter of a dockworker in Liverpool, was given The Queenaposs support for her tell-all book - The Other Side of The Coin: The Queen, The Dresser and the Wardrobe. The decision to support the book is unprecedented, proving just how highly regarded she is by the Queen.After starting in  as a dresser, Angela is now solely responsible for how Her Majesty looks in public and has even made several of her most memorable looks. Love the royals for the Mirroraposs daily newsletter to get all the latest news on the Queen, Charles, Kate, Wills, Meghan, Harry and the rest of The Firm. Click here to sign up. And who knows, maybe Angela is busy at work making some outfits for the Queen to wear this Christmas Thataposs because the monarch has told her family she is well enough to host Christmas at Sandringham this month after recovering from a back sprain. The -year-old assured them she is feeling “far better” and is “looking forward” to the traditional festive get together at her Norfolk estate.  Concern for the Queen’s health has been heightened in recent weeks after she pulled out of a number of major engagements. But a source said: “The Queen has told everyone she is feeling far better of late and is very much looking forward to welcoming them for Christmas. “Like many other families, this will be the first time Her Majesty can gather with her extended family after being kept apart for so long due to the coronavirus pandemic.” Royal fans will be hoping toto the estate on Christmas Day to catch a glimpse of the royals as they walk en masse to and from the th Century St Mary Magdalene Church on the Sandringham property. The Queen is said to be “determined” to attend church with the rest of the family, but will as in previous years be driven to the church to save her walking the short distance.Christmas guests will include Prince Charles and the Duchess of Cornwall and the Duke and Duchess of Cambridge and their three children. news uk-news salt-bae-bosss-reveal-gold-"Salt Bae serves customer a £ gold-wrapped burgerByHannah NearyDanya BazaraaSenior News Reporter:,  Dec Updated:,  Dec | commentsThe boss of Salt Baeaposs famous London restaurant has admitted that gold leaf doesnapost make any dference to the taste of the meat. Nusr-Et Steakhouseaposs boss said the controversial Knightsbridge restaurant serves the best meat in the world and backlash over five figure bills is just talk Items on the menu include an £ steak peppered in gold and a £ burger.Mr Mehmed told MyLondon the most popular dish is Tomahawk steak, which can be covered in gold leaf for up to £,.But Mr Mehmed said the gold leaf makes no dference to meat. He added: It doesnapost improve the taste or change the quality.  But he said: The gold steak is something dferent, it’s the best in London. The restaurant also do vegan dishes - a range of salads - that can also be sprinkled with goldyou fancy it. Salt Bae - real name Nusret Gökçe - is a Turkish chef and social media star, who went viral for his seductive meat seasoning and cooking techniques in . He has multiple steak restaurants around the world, including his native country.  After opening its doors to Londoners in September, the restaurant has come under fire with diners complaining of a £, bill and others saying they paid £, to be treated like babies. But Mr Mehmed is not phased by the haters, insisting you get what you pay for. He said: Some people, they want to just talk.  People have complained because they have seen bills on social media for people who’ve paid £, for a bottle of wine. But you can find these prices all around London. The service and the quality we are providing is extremely high. It’s more interactive than most restaurants - we cook and prepare the food in front of you, like our traditional baklava, which is a very popular dessert. title: school dinner lady sets up
story: School dinner lady sets up café from home during lockdown - and people are loving itLiz Hall created the Walk This Way Café when she was forced to give up her job and look after her -year-old daughter at home during the coronavirus lockdownLiz Hall at her Walk This Way Café in Little Lever Image: ABNM PhotographyByJosie Le VayChiara FiorilloNews Reporter:,  Dec | comments A school dinner lady set up a café from her home during the coronavirus lockdown, attracting locals who enjoy sipping coffee and eating cakes there.Liz Hall created the Walk This Way Café in her house and said that initially, not many people understood the idea behind it because it is in a residential area. However, six months on, the café on Boscow Road in Little Lever, Bolton, Greater Manchester, has many five-star reviews and is loved by the local community.Liz told the Manchester Evening News : Itaposs been really, really positive. Thereaposs nothing like us in the area here.Itaposs something Iaposve always wanted to do. Liz opened Walk This Way Café after she was forced to give up her job during lockdown and stay at home. Her -year-old daughter, who has autism, was sent home from her school before mainstream schools followed suit in a move to protect the most vulnerable children. Because she needed to be at home to look after her daughter, Liz started thinking about opening a café. Liz said: I like being a bit dferent.  Her husband Alan built the shop front and now the café is popular not only with locals, but also with passers-by. Liz said her new business venture has also helped her become closer to the local community. Walk this Way offers sandwiches, hot and cold drinks, chocolates, crisps, and ice lollies - all at affordable prices. I offer a service that I would expect myself, Liz said.A review on Google reads: Fantastic little gem of a cafe, with very friendly and helpful owners. Nothing is too much trouble for them, nice little pit stop during a walk.Love the hot chocolate, will definitely be back, also child and dog friendly. Thank you Alan and Liz for making us feel welcomed and for making our walk much brighter. Another person said: Fab little cafe. Stopped off on a group bike ride today, and got a lovely welcome, nice coffee, and delicious gluten free cookie. One more added: Wow, what a find. Weaposve been walking in this area for years and always thought there should be some refreshments in this area, well now there is.Over the summer, the Walk This Way was open from Monday to Sunday. It now opens its doors on weekends and on some days during the school holidays. You can find out how to get there by clicking here.Read MoreRead MoreMost ReadDont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON GoogleCoronavirusCafe DeliCoronavirus lockdown" data-immediate"data-immediate"Join the lockdown community for surveys on your viewsInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. news uk-news stepmum-only-felt-sorry-herself-"Arthur Labinjo-Hughes: Balloons are released in remembranceByAmy SharpeReporter:,  Dec Updated:,  Dec | commentsArthur Labinjo-Hughesaposs killer didnapost show remorse and only felt sorry for herself in prison, her cellmate has said. This week Emma Tustin, , was sentenced to le with a minimum term of  years for killing her six-year-old step-son. While in remand during the trial, she shared a cell with a prisoner called Elaine for six weeks at Eastwood Park prison, Gloucestershire. The former cellmate claimed that the murderous step-mum never once mentioned Arthur or his death. Arthuraposs father, Thomas Hughes, , was sentenced to  years for manslaughter - but Tustin was said to have been upset that he was cold to her during their trial. “She always felt sorry for herself, Elaine told the Sunday Mirror.  One day she came back from a plea hearing and was upset, so I asked, ‘What’s wrong ’ “She said, ‘He didn’t look at me, Tom never looked at me’. That was the only time I saw her upset about anything.” Elaine had been recalled to jail for battery and criminal damage. She said Tustin used to “laugh and joke” on the phone.  Elaine claimed the mum of four told her own mother she would never see her grandchildren again unless she retracted statements about Arthur. She only discovered the truth about the charges Tustin was facing when she found and read her case paperwork. “We had a fight – it was me more than her. I got angry because I’d read about how he [Arthur] had  bruises and I asked how she wouldn’t notice when she gave him a bath, she added. “She said she just used to give him a towel.  “I pressed the bell and saidthe prison officers didn’t get her out then I’d be staying there a long time.” Tustin was moved to a dferent cell. But Elaine said after inmates learned how Tustin poisoned Arthur with salt, they laced her meals with it. She said: “Some of the things we did were cruel – but she was crueller to Arthur so she deserved it.”  Today dozens of residents paid a touching tribute to Arthur outside the house in Solihull where he was killed. Organised by a local resident, the vigil saw people laying flowers, holding balloons and placing posters and banners paying tribute to Arthur at the property. His maternal grandmother Madeleine Halcrow could be seen wiping away tears at the vigil while wearing a T-shirt bearing his face. The crowd lined the road before letting go of the balloons, some bearing messages, and applauding. Residents, some with tears in their eyes, could be heard saying bye Arthur and fly high always. They then formed a line outside the house before balloons, posters and flowers were placed around the property.  The words You are loved Arthur were put on the boarded-up window. A Birmingham City flag was also placed at the scene, along with a picture of Arthur. The Government has announced a major review into the circumstances which led to the murder, aiming to determine what improvements are needed by the agencies that came into contact with Arthur before his death. The National Child Safeguarding Practice Review Panel will lead the review and will provide additional support to Solihull Childrenaposs Safeguarding Partnership. It emerged in court the boy had been seen by social workers just two months before his death, but they concluded there were no safeguarding concerns. news uk-news uk-travel-rules-explained-new-"Omicron: Dominic Raab says its going to be a great ChristmasByDanya BazaraaSenior News Reporter:,  Dec Updated:,  Dec | comments The spread of the Omicron coronavirus iant has prompted the UK Government to make changes to travel rules again.The Department of Health and Social Caresaid new analysis by the UK Health and Security Agencysuggested the window between infection and infectiousness may be shorter for the Omicron iant, increasing the efficacy of pre-departure testing as it is more likely to identy positive cases before travel. Changes were also made last week to day two tests, requiring people to complete a PCR and isolate until they have a negative result back. The HSA said that as of Saturday a further  cases of the Omicron iant have been reported across the UK -  of them in England. It takes the total number of confirmed cases of the iant in the UK to . The Mirror has explained the latest changes to the travel rules.  Pre departure tests From am on Tuesday, anyone travelling to the UK from countries not on the red list will be required to take a pre-departure test a maximum of  hours before leaving, regardless of their vaccination status. Ministers said it was intended to be a temporary measure following new data showing an increase in the number of cases of the new strain linked to foreign travel. The move, which will be introduced on Tuesday, was welcomed by Labour which has been pressing for theof pre-departure tests since the iant was first identied in South Africa. But the party criticised the Government for not acting sooner. It means passengers travelling to the UK will have to take either a PCR or a lateral flow test up to a maximum of  hours before they depart regardless of their vaccination status.  We have always said we would act swtlywe need tothe changing data requires it, Mr Javid said. These are temporary measures we want to remove them as soon as we possibly can, but before we learn more about Omicron it is right that we have these measures in place. The Department of Health and Social Caresaid it had acted in part because said new analysis by the UK Health and Security Agencysuggested the window between infection and infectiousness may be shorter for the Omicron iant. Day two tests upon arrival to the UK Last week, the introduction of compulsory PCR tests for Covid- for everyone arriving in the UK was announced. It was announced that all vaccinated passengers arriving in the UK must take a day  PCR test and self-isolate until they receive a negative result. The test can be taken on or before day two.  Under the previous rules, vaccinated arrivals simply needed a PCR or lateral flow test on day two. Under the new rules which have come into force, you will need to self-isolate for the first two days back in the UK. On day two, you will need to take a PCR test - andthe result is negative, you will be allowed to end your self-isolation. As for travellers who are unvaccinated or partially vaccinated, existing rules continue to apply. This means thatyou are ing from non-red list country, then you will need to take a pre-departure test and self-isolate at home for  days during which you need to take PCR tests on days two and eight. Countries on the red list Last week it was announced that the following countries have been added to the red list: Angola, Botswana, Eswatini, Lesotho, Malawi, Mozambique, Namibia, South Africa, Zambia and Zimbabwe. Nigeria was also added to the Governmentaposs travel red list. From am on Monday, only British and Irish nationals travelling from the country will be allowed into the UK and must isolate in a Government-managed quarantine hotel for  days. UK arrivals ing from red list countries are required to stay in a quarantine hotel for  nights, with costs of up to £, per adult. The developing situation is unsurprisingly causing some concern amongst Brits who have booked holidays in the coming weeks.  Industry reaction The travel sector said theof pre-departure tests was another hammer blow for an industry which was just beginning to pick up again after the devastation wrought by the pandemic. Clive Wratten, chief executive of the Business Travel Association, said it directly contradicted assurances given by Transport Secretary Grant Shapps and he called on the Government to step in and support the sector. The introduction of pre-departure testing with little warning is a hammer blow to the business travel industry, he said. Public safety is a priority, but businesses will fail, travellers will be stranded and livelihoods devastated by the lack of coherent plans from Government. Tim Alderslade, chief executive of the industry body Airlines UK, said the rapidly changing measures meant planning was becoming impossible. It is premature to hit millions of passengers and industry before we see the full data. We donapost have the clinical evidence, he said. These measures must be removed as quickly as possible in line with the speed of the booster programme. title: woman who tried sue gp
story: Woman who tried to sue GP for £K after missed cancer diagnosis branded dishonestSara Iddon attended an appointment with Dr Karen Warner in January  and complained about a lump in her left breast, a court heard. She was later branded dishonest by a judgeSwimmers take on the  Great North Swim in Lake WindermereImage: newcastle chronicleByNeal Keeling:,  Dec | commentsA woman who tried to sue her GP for £, for damages after they missed a breast cancer diagnosis has been branded dishonest by a judge. Sara Iddon attended an appointment with Dr Karen Warner in January  and complained about a lump in her left breast, a court heard.The GP recorded there was no discrete lump and reassured the woman, the Manchester Evening News reports.Eight months later, the woman from Preston, Lancashire, had another appointment at the same medical practice but with a dferent doctor, saying she noticed a change in the shape of her left breast. After having a mammogram, Mrs Iddon was diagnosed with breast cancer and on December , she had surgery and breast reconstruction.  Later, the woman had chemotherapy and radiotherapy and between December  and October , she underwent lipo modelling of her reconstructed left breast. In June , Mrs Iddon made a claim of damages for £, saying she had suffered avoidable pain, loss of amenity, and reduced movement in her left arm. In September , a consultant psychologist saw Mrs Iddon and wrote: She no longer runs but does try to swim a bit in the swimming pool. However this is not anywhere near the level she was at prior to the alleged negligence...she used to swim for miles. In November that year, a consultant in pain medicine examined her and recorded: The pain is constant, severe, agonising, aching, sharp, throbbing, tingling, and horrible in character. He added: Mrs Iddon was fit and she used to run four times a week as well as she had training for a half marathon that she took part in. She used to swim in open waters as well as take her dog for a walk. She cannot do these leisure activities now because of a lack of fitness and tiredness. However, Manchester High Court heard Mrs Iddon had taken part in a nighttime open water swim the month before. By December , Mrs Iddon had increased her damages claim to £, alleging she was suffering from severe chronic post-surgical pain and associated dysesthesia and numbness in the left chest wall, left shoulder arm ad both hips causing severe disability, fatigue, and psychological injury. In May , Mrs Iddon served a total claim of £,, including for loss of past and future earnings and care. On July , , Dr Warner made an open admission of liability and a district judge ordered the defendant to make an interim payment of £,. However, despite admitting breach of duty, the GP later alleged that Mrs Iddonaposs claim should be dismissed because she had been fundamentally dishonest in relation to the claim, and the judge agreed.An intelligence analyst, Mr Richard Vaughan, said that on September , , Chris Barnes, Mrs Iddonaposs brother, posted on Facebook : Sara is not a victim but a fighter carrying on with her le running and swimming like she did before. In addition, it was revealed that on November , , Sara Iddon posted on Facebook: Fantastic night swim with Christine, Swimease   , brilliantly organised and really good fun.A Google search revealed that Sara Iddon finished th in the Great North Swimrun  which took place on June ,  and that she and Andrew Iddon finished th and st in the Great Scottish Swim Aquathon which took place on August , .Mrs Iddon first denied she had taken part in any events, but later admitted it. She stated that she acquired CBD hemp oil and a substance she believed to be cannabis oil to cope with the effects of breast cancer. She claimed that with the aid of these substances, she was able to participate in eight sporting events. In a new court statement, Mrs Iddon failed to mention she had taken part in another event - a k run on May ,  at Worden Park. In his judgement, HHJ Sephton, said he found that Mrs Iddon deliberately omitted to refer to the Worden Park run as she thought she had got away with not revealing it. He also added: I reject the submission that the consumption of either hemp oil or cannabis oil had any effect at all on Mrs Iddon’s performance in the sporting events in which she took part. I find that when she took part in those sporting events, she performed without the aid of these substances. He said: I conclude that, by the incomplete or frankly misleading accounts Mrs Iddon gave to the medical experts, she intended to mislead the court about her capabilities. By the standards of ordinary decent people, her actions were dishonest. What is more, I believe that Mrs Iddon knew that they were dishonest. The effect of her lies was to seek to inflate the value of a case which I have held to be worth just over £, into a case worth over £,. I regard Mrs Iddon’s dishonesty in this case to be very grave. She lied repeatedly about her injuries, she continued to lie after she had been found out and, most seriously, she persuaded others to lie on her behalf. Mrs Iddon suffered serious and distressing consequences because of the defendant’s breach of duty. Regrettably, she lied about how serious her condition was, and persuaded others to lie to support her account. I feel unable to rely on Mrs Iddon’s evidence I have been forced to look to other sources of information. It may be that the evidence I feel able to rely on is incomplete so that some of the losses Mrs Iddon suffered have not been taken into account. If that is so, she only has herself to blame. I conclude that Mrs Iddon has been fundamentally dishonest in relation to her claim. I am not persuaded that she would suffer substantial injusticeI were to dismiss her claim. I record that, but for the dismissal of her claim, I would have awarded Mrs Iddon £,.. Mrs Iddon used the interim payment to buy a house, but may now be forced to repay it.Most ReadDont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON Breast cancerCourt caseSwimming poolsFitness" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. news uk-news worlds-favourite-christmas-film-according-"The Nightmare Before Christmas trailer from TouchstoneByEmily Sleight:,  Dec Updated:,  Dec | commentsThere’s nothing better than curling up on your sofa and sticking on a classic Christmas film with a Baileys or two. Whether you like a classic festive movie or something a little more romantic, there’s always plenty of choice.Christmas isn’t Christmas without a film night, and PoundToy has ranked the best family Christmas movies of all time.Analysing factors like audience scores and box office revenues, the results may shock some. Coming in at first place is Tim Burton’s The Nightmare Before Christmas.  Yes, the age old debate is whether this classic Disney flick is a Halloween or Christmas film but maybe thataposs worked in its favour giving it a double whammy of views. It was released in  with an IMDB score of . and a box office revenue of a whopping .m. Out of ten it scores . and bags first place out of our ten classic Christmas movie contenders.  Ranking second place is Miracle on th Street which follows Kris Kringle who plays the role of Santa visiting children at a department store. This classic is rated  by critics on Metacritic, and a .  by viewers on IMDb, it’s safe to say this one is loved by many. At third place is Home Alone, which seems to have a more popular search volume in the UK including cities Manchester and London. It has a box office revenue of ..m and a total Christmas ranking of .  and is another perfect option for a cosy film night.Surprisingly, Elf came th in the overall ranking, but is still the most popular Christmas in the UK, with over . million UK Google searches in the past year.The other rankings might disappoint The Muppets fans, which scored th place, followed by The Polar Express and The Chronicles Of Narnia. It was found to be the favourite film in cities such as Brighton, Cambridge and Durham. news us-news flight-records-show-prince-andrew-"Prince Andrew affair ‘not going away’ says expertByDanya BazaraaSenior News Reporter:,  Dec Updated:,  Dec Flight records show Prince Andrew travelled on Jeffrey Epsteinaposs Lolita Express private jet at least four times, it is claimed. The alleged trips reportedly included flights to and from Epsteinaposs private Caribbean island, Little St James. Flight records seen by the Mail on Sunday suggest Prince Andrewaposs first flight on board Epsteinaposs black Gulfstream II jet was to the billionaireaposs private Caribbean island in the US Virgin Islands on February , . According to the flight logs, Epstein, Ghislaine Maxwell and one of the Dukeaposs personal protection officers were also on board. They landed at Cyril E King Airport on the island of St Thomas then were shuttled to Little St James on one of Epsteinaposs helicopters, reports say.But The Daily Mail says a source close to the Prince reportedly said in  that the Duke has aposno recollectionapos of being on the  flight. Little St James is now known as apospaedophile islandapos because of the horric abuse that took place there. It has been reported before that Prince Andrew visited the island, but he insists he never saw anything untoward. The flight logs allegedly show that after spending three nights on the island, Prince Andrew went to West Palm Beach where Epstein owned a £ million home. It is claimed the records also show he flew on Epsteinaposs Gulfstream from Teterboro Airport in New Jersey to West Palm Beach on May , . And it is alleged that Prince Andrew took a flight on the plane from London Luton to Edinburgh on September ,  – six weeks after Epstein was arrested for sex offences.  The private jet has been described as having thick burgundy carpets, leather executive chairs and a gourmet chef on board. Guests were said to be given dishes including Wagyu beef steak and caviar blinis as well as vintage Cristal champagne. The claims come after a court earlier heard that a woman who has accused Ghislaine Maxwell of grooming her to be abused by paedophile Jeffrey Epstein once took a flight with Prince Andrew. The victim, known in court as “Jane’, was asked about her time on board the late billionaire’s private jet nicknamed the ‘Lolita Expressapos. Cross-examined by defence counsel for Maxwell during the British socialiteaposs sex abuse case, attorney Laura Menninger said: “Do you remember Prince Andrew being on a flight with you ” Jane, whose identity is protected, replied: “Yes”.  The testimony which came earlier this month is the first time an alleged victim who witnessed the Duke of York, , on an Epstein flight has appeared before a jury. The flight, which aposJaneapos is listed as being on board with Andrew was when she -years-old flying from the billionaireaposs ranch in New Mexico to his home in Palm Beach. The Duke has been under fire for his close ties to the late paedophile, who committed suicide in August  as he awaited trial for sex trafficking. Andrew is also facing a lawsuit from Virginia Giuffre, who claims Epstein and Maxwell made her have sex with the UK royal three times, starting in  when she was . The royal has emphatically denied the allegations and any wrongdoing. title: woman lured tinder date chopped
story: Woman lured on Tinder date chopped into  pieces by twisted sex cult killersVictim Sydney Loofe, who lived in lived in Lincoln, Nebraska, USA, was chopped into  pieces by twisted sex cult killers Aubrey Trail and Bailey Boswell after a Tinder dateSydney Loofes body was found dumped and in pieces in a fieldByGail Shortland:,  Dec Updated:,  Dec | commentsDressed in a white jacket and a cream shirt, Sydney Loofe took a selfie and shared the photo on Snapchat with the caption, “Ready for my date.” Sydney, , was smiling for the camera and looked excited. She had even added a heart-eyed emoji. It was good to see Sydney happy. Her loved ones knew she’d struggled with depression, but she was always trying to stay positive. A tattoo on her arm read, “Everything will be wonderful someday.” And her new romance was making her feel hopeful. It was  November  and Sydney lived in Lincoln, Nebraska, where she worked as a cashier at a hardware store. Her parents, George and Susie, lived three hours away, but they would get together as often as they could and messaged each other constantly. Sydney had told her friends that she’d met a woman called Audrey on Tinder. She’d even shared Audrey’s picture with them. She had been on one date with Audrey two days earlier – where they had simply driven around getting to know each other. Now it was time for the second date and she headed out.  But the next morning, Sydney didn’t turn up for work. She wasn’t ing messages from her parents, so they got in their car and drove straight to her apartment. They found Sydney’s cat Mimzy hungry and abandoned and knew something bad had happened. Sydney would never have neglected her cat. Her car was still there and her mobile was turned off. They filed a missing person’s report with the police. The last time her phone was on, it was in Wilber – about  miles away. Fears were that Sydney had been abducted and her parents made an emotional public plea for her safe . Investigators focused on Sydney’s date, Audrey, and tracked down her phone number after linking with her on Tinder. The woman who answered admitted going on a date with Sydney, but said she’d left her at a friend’s house afterwards. She couldn’t recall where that was. Police noted that Audrey was reluctant to share basic details about herself. Eventually, officers discovered that “Audrey” was a woman called Bailey Boswell, then . She lived with her older boyfriend Aubrey Trail, then , in Wilber. They were both named as persons of interest. Boswell had been using a dferent mobile to send messages to Sydney and that phone, as well as Trail’s and Sydney’s, led the police to a location  miles west of Wilber. There, on  December, Sydney’s body was found. Her dismembered remains were stuffed in rubbish bags in ditches in a field near Omaha.  Sydney’s body had been cut up into  pieces – some of her organs and body parts were never found. The cause of death was suffocation and she had put up a fight in her final moments. Her earlobe was torn and she had bruising on her wrists, the back of the head and her inner thighs. She’d clearly been restrained before she was deprived of air. Investigators were certain that Boswell and Trail were involved. They turned out to be a very disturbing couple. Boswell had met Trail when he answered her online advert for massages. She had a young daughter who she had lost custody of. Trail and Boswell had a lot in common – including dark fantasies. They moved into a basement flat together in Wilber in June  and started defrauding antiques dealers. The pair enjoyed group sex with other women, who they met through Tinder. Trail told them stories about “gaining power” from killing people. Police determined that Boswell had lured Sydney into a trap and she had been murdered. There was even surveillance footage of Trail and Boswell out before Sydney’s date, where they bought tools and bleach. The pair were arrested in June  and charged with Sydney’s murder. Right from the start, Trail was a liar. He told a newspaper that Sydney had agreed to be part of a sexual fantasy with him and two other women, while Boswell was passed out on drugs in another room. It had got rough and something had become tight around Sydney’s neck. Trail also told his lawyers that he’d had a “sex party” with just Boswell and Sydney. They had all had sex but while Sydney was handcuffed, he had choked her with an electrical cord and had killed her. But even in the courtroom during the trial in , Trail would change his version of events again. The prosecutors said that the twisted couple had already planned on killing someone before finding Sydney on Tinder. Boswell would connect with the woman after she and Trail picked a target together by looking on social media. Hours before Sydney’s death, Trail and Boswell were buying the tools and supplies used to dismember her. They had even chosen Sydney as she lived  miles away from her family, hoping her disappearance wouldn’t be noticed for a while. They were wrong. Then, during proceedings, Trail grew angry at negative testimony about his girlfriend’s guilt and screamed, “Bailey is innocent and I curse you all!” before using a blade to cut his throat. Trail was taken to hospital and ended up missing most of his own trial. He ed to testy in his defence with scars on his neck. The defence said that Sydney had agreed to be filmed doing “sexual asphyxiation” infor money. But when Trail took to the stand, he shocked his own legal team by admitting that was also a lie. The killer said he had spun stories to confuse the investigators. “It was only me, Bailey and Sydney there the night Sydney died. There were no two other girls there. There was no , paid for a sexual fantasy,” Trail said. He claimed Sydney’s killing wasn’t planned, but she had been lured to the apartment by Boswell and Sydney had “freaked out”. They’d hoped she would join their sex ring and criminal activities. When she resisted, Trail killed and dismembered her with a saw to “protect” their lestyle. And the court were given a horric insight into that lestyle. Three women testied about being lured into Trail and Boswell’s sex cult via Tinder between June  and the November Sydney died. Trail said he was a vampire who could fly and read minds. He and Boswell both alleged they could gain more “powers” by killing people – even morethey tortured them first. The women would have sex with Trail and Boswell in exchange for an allowance. They also helped in the antique business scams. Trail made them call him “Daddy” and he would call Boswell “The Queen Witch”. There were strict rules about staying in touch with Trail and they spoke about being punished. If they broke rules, they would be slapped or even choked with a belt. When one woman left the sex cult, Trail had threatened to kill her familyshe told anyone. The jury took just three hours to deliberate. The couple were both found guilty of first-degree murder, criminal conspiracy to commit murder and improper disposal of human remains.  In June this year, at a sentencing for Trail in front of a three-judge , he gave a statement. He admitted he’d killed Sydney but insisted it wasn’t premeditated. He had killed her because he was worried that Sydney would go to the policehe let her go. “I won’t say I’m sorry, as that would be an insult to you after what I put you through,” Trail said to Sydney’s family. “And I won’t ask for forgiveness as I don’t believe there is such a thing. I have done some terrible things in my le, but this is the only thing I have ever done that I feel real regret about.” The judges said Trail had displayed a “cold, calculated” level of planning, pointing out that he had even bragged about the killing afterwards and joked that he had drunk Sydney’s blood. They said that dismembering her body was needless and done to satisfy his “intellectual and sexual curiosity”. Trail was given the death penalty. At Boswell’s sentencing last month, she also faced the death penalty. She begged for her le to be spared for her “daughter’s sake”. The judges said Sydney had found herself in the killers’ flat, outnumbered and unable to defend herself. “Boswell’s actions and words demonstrate that she had no regard for the le of Sydney Loofe beyond her own pleasure,” one judge said. But one judge didn’t agree on the death penalty, so Boswell was sentenced to le in prison without parole. Her legal team said they would appeal. news weird-news happy-corgis-compared-bunnies-hilariously-"Group of corgis spread autumnal joy as they play in huge leaf pileByChloe Bowen:,  Dec | commentsAn adorable pack of corgis got excited over a huge stack of leaves that their owner had gathered up, and their joy is infectious. Thanks to the oak trees in their back garden, the fallen leaves have given five playful pups a new game to keep them entertained. The stack of leaves is much bigger than them, which means the only way for them to move around is to hop and bounce - and the result is hilarious. If it wasnapost for their thrill-seeking bunny hops, it would be hard to spot the tiny dogs in the leaf pile. Their owner, Mark Trippi, from South Carolina, USA, caught the precious moment on video.  Mark, , said: “They like to watch me blow the leaves in a big pile then they run around and play tag while running through the leaves.” The five pups, named Rusty, Skillet, Sierra, Muffin and Willow can be seen up to their ears in leaves, bouncing towards one another. One of them gives a little bark of excitement while another jumps to urge the others to start another game of chase. Mark says they like to hide in the pile, which isnapost hard due to the size of them. The TeamDogs Christmas Gt Guide, sponsored by Keep Wales Tidy, is packed with more than  treats, toys, gadgets and garments to make every dog’s tail wag with holly jolly joy on December . Weaposve tried and tested many of the gts on our own TeamDogs friends so you can ensure they’re worth placing under the tree for your most special member of the family. To download our Christmas Gt Guide for free simply subscribe to the TeamDogs newsletter. At one point in the video, one or two little corgis disappear into the pile before popping up into sight again. Mark and his we Paula have had corgis for  years and he says the breed like to make everyone happy. The truck service manager added: “It gives us joy to see our corgis having fun and playing together. You will see how they look back at us to seewe are smiling.” The video caught lots of attention on Facebook.One user said: “Leaf bunnies!” Another said “Needles in a haystack  NOOOO... Corgis in a leaf-stack.” Others have commented on how adorable they are and how much it has made them smile. title: make up fan tests 100
story: Make-up fan tests  mascaras to see which ones to avoid and her absolute favouriteA beauty fan who has almost , followers on TikTok has tested  mascaras to see which are her favourite, and which ones didnt live up to her expectationsKelly tested  mascaras to see which was the best and worst Image: Kelly Rose Sarno TikTokByPaige HollandShowbiz Audience Writer:,  Dec Updated:,  Dec | commentsWith so many mascaras on the market, it can be tough to know which one is for you. There are mascaras that promise thick, voluminous lashes, and others that give you extreme . But not all of them do what they say on the tin. Thankfully, we donapost need to spend a fortune deciphering the good from the bad as make-up fan Kelly Rose Sarno has done the hard work for us.Kelly has built a following of almost , on her TikTok account @kellyrosesarno, with her beauty tutorials. In a recent video, Kelly ranked the top  best and worst mascaras, with the caption: Is @benefitcosmetics Bad Gal Bang still my # favourite  Here is my updated top  best and worst! For more of the news you care about, straight to your inbox, sign up for one of our daily newsletters here. She explained: I have tested over  mascaras. I’m the girl that tests out mascaras so that you don’t have to and here is my updated top ten and top worst. Kelly kicks off the video with the top ten mascaras to avoid. She said: “Kicking off the top  do not is the Bite upswing mascara, Mayblelline snapscara, Kat Von Dee go big or go home, Ulta twisted volume, YSL volume effect, Blinc original tubing mascara, Smashbox super fan mascara, besty long curl mascara, baddie lashes mascara. “Number two on my do not buy list is the mascara from Physicians formula with the fibre extensions and my number one do not buy mascara is the Florence by Mills which makes me so sad because I love her, but you can literally see how bad this mascara is, right through the tube.” Then, she moves on to her favourite mascaras. She said: I will have you know, I do not take this lightly. I am looking for a formula that lasts, that gives me , separation and volume. Kicking off top ten with Ilia limitless lash mascara, Maybelline the falsies push-up drama, Essence lash princess Aurora volume mascara from the Disney princess line, L’Oreal Paris unlimited mascara , Vivienne Sabo Paris Cabaret première, Patrick Ta major volume mascara, Elf lash it loud, Butter London stroke of wow volumising mascara. Coming in at number  but it’s really . is Rare Beauty - I absolutely love this mascara, it works on all levels. But after  mascaras, Bad Gal Bang from Benefit still reigns supreme. This mascara gives me , separation, volume and the tube lasts literally forever. After over  mascaras, she is still reigning supreme. Since being posted, the video has racked up almost , likes and , comments from thankful viewers, with many agreeing that Benefitaposs Bag Gal Bang mascara is their favourite too. One person said: I totally agree... Bad Gal Bang #. Another wrote: I bought the Bag Girl Bang after watching this vid and IT IS WONDERFUL. Thank you for the recommendation!! A third said: You should make your own brand. While someone  said: I have literally used LaposOreal Voluminous mascara since I was in high school and Iaposm in my s. I have tried many but always go back.Have you got a story to share We want to hear all about it. news weird-news my-man-kids-live-dferent-"Blended family live in separate suites of same houseByEmma RosemurgeyAudience Writer:,  Dec | comments A couple have revealed their rather unorthodox way of living as a blended, yet unblended family, as they live in two separate suites within the same home, but swear it works perfectly for them. Shelley Hunt and Peter Verge, from Penticton, Canada, all live together in one big home with their five children, but not in the way that you might think.Mum-of-two Shelley lives in one suite within the home with her children from a previous marriage, while Peter lives in a suite upstairs with his three kids, and in all honesty, it sounds perfect. The couple have been together for a number of years now, and both have joint custody of all five kids on the same schedule, meaning they either have all five kids at once, or none of them, giving them alone time to enjoy as a couple. After previously revealing their unusual living situation, the couple recently took to TikTok to answer all the burning questions people had about their family dynamic. I live on the upper floor, I have three bedrooms for me and my three kids and Shelley is on the main floor with her two. We have our own entrances, thereaposs a door that locks in between, Peter explained. I pay  percent of everything and Shelley pays  and thataposs based on square footage. Iaposm responsibly for my suite, I cook, I clean, and the same thing for Shelly downstairs. For more of the news you care about, straight to your inbox, sign up for one of our daily newsletters here. Shelley added: Our suites are really separate so we have our own rooms but we have shared custody on all five of our children on the same schedule, so we either have all five of them or none of them andtheyaposre not here, we open the door and strangely, we sleep in my room, but we use Peteraposs living space aposcause itaposs cooler. Explaining a little bit about how they came to be in that situation, Shelley explained that they were both looking to get onto the property ladder very early in their relationship, so it made financial sense to buy together, while still maintaining some separation for the sake of their children. Despite things being a little unorthodox, the couple believe their children get along better with one another than they wouldaposve done had they been living in closer proximity with each other. We believe the kids get along better because they have space, they call us a family, they call each other step-siblings, that was totally on their terms, we didnapost push that language on them, Shelley said. We do all of our holidays and birthdays together and we do dinner a couple of nights a week altogether.Do you have a story to share  We want to hear all about it.
